mistakes: No significant common mistakes, generally high quality answers. Some parts allowed reuse of answers from earlier parts.
No specific mistakes noted; generally high quality answers.
Candidates struggled, did not thoroughly read the question, or made the same point multiple times.
Preference to write rather than draw (e.g., UML) made it harder to convey details.
Some candidates struggled with the hypergeometric distribution (parts c, d). Part g was hard but many mastered it. Part e was ambiguously phrased.
No specific mistakes noted; almost all candidates did very well.
Most candidates could not solve part (c). Many left parts (d) and (e) blank or performed poorly due to lack of time, despite being bookwork.

Part (a) justification was poor for many. Not all recognized Counting Sort or could append in constant time (b.i). Pointer manipulation was not impressive (b.ii). Proving optimality was impossible for those who missed the linear-time solution (b.iii).
Imprecision in student writing and proofs. Part (c) was challenging; students answered glibly without thinking through potential issues with naive answers.
No comments provided.
Trouble finding minterms (b.i), errors in Q-M simplification (b.ii). Explanations for circuit function (c) lacked detail.
Parts (a) and (b.i) were too straightforward. Some students could not prove minimum states in (b.ii). More difficulties with metastability question (c), especially (c.ii).
Students failed to answer all parts of (a). CFS was not well understood or applied in (b), and candidates failed to state assumptions. Part (c) often focused on a single reason.

Part (b) too easy. Part (c) required clearer descriptions. In (d), answers for TLB were not practical, only addressed the VALID bit, and not the DIRTY bit; students failed to answer the whole question.
No specific mistakes noted among those who attempted it; answers were as expected. Notation difference from lectures might have reduced attempts.
No specific mistakes noted; answers were consistent with solutions.
No comments provided.
No comments provided.
Some students mixed up sections and retractions (a). In part (d)(i), students assumed a trivial definition of bijection. In part (c), confusion between injectivity and determinacy was common.
Many found part (b)(ii) very difficult, failing to establish bounds or making incorrect arguments. Few students attempted the 'freebie' part (c), possibly due to time or course design.
Few candidates considered the duality of intersection and union in (a). In (d), many assumed 'definitely storing' instead of a case split. No credit for new operations not related to part c.
In part (c), some interpreted 'might be' as 'are' instead of considering a case split.
In part (a)(iii), very few noted HDR colour requires floating point or display encoding. In part (c), many made mistakes with the order of matrix operations.
Many did not identify 'banding' (a-i) or 'aliasing' (a-ii). Part (a-iii) was difficult. Part (b) was intended as moderate but proved difficult, with many not attempting it.

In (a), some listed groups without using stakeholder analysis techniques. In (b), some lacked full Heuristic Evaluation detail. In (c), interview questions were not always meaningful or relevant. In (d), few described the qualitative data analysis process well.

In (a), some requirements were inappropriate or too brief. In (b), designs were not user-group specific or lacked detail. In (c), user personas were not well-described or guidance was generic. In (d), principles were mentioned without describing interactive improvement.
Section B was a high-stakes part, requiring probability computations; students either got full marks or zero, with failure impacting Section C. Section E also had a low median score.
Some errors in the first question (standard definitions and calculation). The last part was challenging.
Part (c) regarding the feature independence assumption was not given frequently, possibly due to a lack of smoothing context.
